title: Dense-in-itself
summary: In general topology, a subset A {\displaystyle A} of a topological space is said to be dense-in-itself[1][2] or crowded[3][4] if A {\displaystyle A} has no isolated point. Equivalently, A {\displaystyle A} is dense-in-itself if every point of A {\displaystyle A} is a limit point of A {\displaystyle A} . Thus A {\displaystyle A} is dense-in-itself if and only if A ⊆ A ′ {\displaystyle A\subseteq A'} , where A ′ {\displaystyle A'} is the derived set of A {\displaystyle A} .
